title: Vaughan Cox
text:
<a href="General%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">General</a> Sir Herbert Vaughan Cox, (12 July 1860 – 8 October 1923) was a British officer in the <a href="British%20Indian%20Army">Indian Army</a>.
Early life.
Cox was born in <a href="Watford">Watford</a>, the son of the <a href="Rector%20%28ecclesiastical%29">Rector</a> of <a href="Upper%20Chelsea">Upper Chelsea</a>. He was educated at <a href="Charterhouse%20School">Charterhouse</a> and the <a href="Royal%20Military%20College%2C%20Sandhurst">Royal Military College, Sandhurst</a>, and was commissioned into the <a href="25th%20Foot">25th Foot</a> (later the <a href="King%27s%20Own%20Scottish%20Borderers">King's Own Scottish Borderers</a>) in 1880.
Early military service.
Posted to <a href="India">India</a>, he served in the closing stages of the <a href="Second%20Anglo-Afghan%20War">Second Anglo-Afghan War</a> and was promoted <a href="lieutenant">lieutenant</a>. He transferred to the <a href="Madras%20Staff%20Corps">Madras Staff Corps</a> in 1882 and served in the <a href="Third%20Anglo-Burmese%20War">Third Anglo-Burmese War</a> of 1885–1886 with the <a href="21st%20Madras%20Infantry%20%28Pioneers%29">21st Madras Infantry</a>.
Cox then briefly served as <a href="adjutant">adjutant</a> of the <a href="South%20India%20Railway%20Volunteer%20Corps">South India Railway Volunteer Corps</a> before being appointed Deputy Assistant <a href="Adjutant-General">Adjutant-General</a> for <a href="Musketry">Musketry</a> in <a href="Burma">Burma</a>. Soon afterwards he was appointed DAAG of Imperial Service Troops. He was promoted <a href="Captain%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">captain</a> in 1891. In 1894 he became an inspector of the contingents supplied by the <a href="Indian%20Princely%20States">Indian Princely States</a>. He served on the <a href="Mohmand%20campaign%20of%201897%E2%80%9398">Mohmand</a> and <a href="Tirah%20Expedition">Tirah Expedition</a>s, being promoted <a href="major">major</a> on 14 January 1900. Later that year he served in <a href="China">China</a> during the <a href="Boxer%20Rebellion">Boxer Rebellion</a>, for which he received the <a href="China%20War%20Medal%20%281900%29">China War Medal (1900)</a>. The medal was presented to him in person by the <a href="George%20V">Prince of Wales</a> on 2 July 1902, following a parade in London of Indian troops visiting the United Kingdom for the <a href="Coronation%20of%20King%20Edward%20VII%20and%20Queen%20Alexandra">Coronation of King Edward VII and Queen Alexandra</a>.
Return to India.
Returning to India in 1902, he spent five years in command of his regiment, the <a href="69th%20Punjabis">69th Punjabis</a>, as a temporary <a href="lieutenant-colonel">lieutenant-colonel</a>. He was promoted substantive lieutenant-colonel in 1904 and <a href="Brevet%20%28military%29">brevet</a> <a href="colonel">colonel</a> in 1907. He was promoted substantive colonel and became Assistant <a href="Quartermaster-General">Quartermaster-General</a> for Mobilisation later in 1907. Nine months later he was appointed Deputy Quartermaster-General for India, in which post he served for three years. In 1911 he was appointed military member of the <a href="Coronation">Coronation</a> <a href="Durbar%20%28court%29">Durbar</a> Committee with the temporary rank of <a href="brigadier-general">brigadier-general</a>, for which he was appointed <a href="Companion%20of%20the%20Order%20of%20the%20Star%20of%20India">Companion of the Order of the Star of India</a> (CSI) later that year.
Commander at Rawalpindi.
Cox's next post was as commander of the 4th Infantry Brigade at <a href="Rawalpindi">Rawalpindi</a>. He was appointed <a href="Companion%20of%20the%20Order%20of%20the%20Bath">Companion of the Order of the Bath</a> (CB) in the 1912 Birthday Honours. He then took command of the 2nd (Nowshera) Infantry Brigade. When the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a> broke out, he was given command of the <a href="29th%20Indian%20Brigade">29th Indian Brigade</a> in Egypt, <a href="Arabia">Arabia</a> and <a href="Gallipoli">Gallipoli</a>, where he was wounded. He was appointed <a href="Knight%20Commander%20of%20the%20Order%20of%20St%20Michael%20and%20St%20George">Knight Commander of the Order of St Michael and St George</a> (KCMG) in October 1915 for distinguished services in the field. In 1916, he was appointed Colonel of his old regiment, the 69th Punjabis.
Service in Egypt and retirement.
He then commanded the <a href="4th%20Division%20%28Australia%29">4th Australian Division</a> in Egypt and in France from 1916 to 1917, when he became <a href="Military%20Secretary%20to%20the%20India%20Office">Military Secretary to the India Office</a>, where he remained until his retirement in January 1921. He was promoted <a href="lieutenant-general">lieutenant-general</a> in January 1917 for distinguished service in the field. In 1919 he was appointed to the <a href="Esher%20Committee">Esher Committee</a> to look into Indian Army administration and organisation. He was promoted <a href="general">general</a> in 1920, and appointed <a href="Knight%20Grand%20Cross%20of%20the%20Order%20of%20the%20Bath">Knight Grand Cross of the Order of the Bath</a> (GCB) in the <a href="1921%20Birthday%20Honours">1921 Birthday Honours</a> following his retirement.
